content:
• Monday, August 5, 2013

  • Asia broadly lower, RBA in focus

    • Shares of Sony fall 5% in Japan after the company's board categorically rejects Dan Loeb's idea for an entertainment business spinoff. Also weighing on Japanese shares is the yen which, at ¥97.96, is firmer by 0.35% against the dollar. The Nikkei is down 1.5%.
    • In Australia, the ASX slips 0.39% and the aussie is steady ahead of an expected RBA rate cut.
    • Elsewhere in the region: The Hang Seng slides 1.83% while the Shanghai Composite is off 0.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:45 PM
  • HOLX

    More on Hologic earnings

    • Hologic (NASDAQ:HOLX) FQ3 beats slightly on the the bottom line but comes up a bit short on top.
    • Net earnings swung to a loss on higher charges restructuring and acquisition-related costs as well as other one-time items.
    • Looking forward, the company forecast FQ4 EPS of $0.36 to $0.37 on revenue of $615M to $625M, below Street estimates of $0.44 on $651M in revenue.
    • For the year, it lowers its per-share earnings estimate to $1.46 to $ 1.47, from its previous estimate for $1.54 to $1.56, but affirms its revenue outlook. Shares -2.7% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:50 PM
  • NLS

    More on Nautilus earnings

    • Nautilus (NYSE:NLS) Q2 misses across the board as the company was dealt with slowing sales and tough Y/Y comps in its retail business due to customers accelerating their normal buying pattern in anticipation of a price increase implement in Q3 last year.
    • Net earnings swung to a profit on an income tax benefit, masking over an 8.4% decline in total revenue.
    • Sales in the larger direct unit rose 2.5% to $25.3M, while sales in its retail business slipped 27% to $10.2M.
    • Gross margin widened to 47.8% from 43.4%, as lower overhead costs helped to mitigate the sales slump.
    • Shares -11.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:38 PM
  • PAA

    Profits slide at Plains All American, PAA Natural Gas

    • Plains All American's (NYSE:PAA) Q2 earnings tumbled 23% Y/Y, while gas-storage affiliate PAA Natural Gas Storage's (NYSE:PNG) Q2 earnings slipped 2.5% as the companies were hurt by higher operating costs.
    • At Plains, operating margin fell to 3.7% from 4.7%; operating expenses increased 6.3%; again raised its capital spending view for the year, to $1.6B from $1.4B.
    • At PAA Natural Gas, revenue from hub services and merchant storage, which includes natural gas sales, rose 22%; operating costs rose 18%.
    • PAA -1.9% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:23 PM | 3 Comments
  • KND

    More on Kindred Healthcare earnings

    • Kindred Healthcare (NYSE:KND) Q2 misses across the board, as total revenue fell slightly from the same period last year due to federal sequestration cuts and bottom line margins were hit by impairment charges.
    • RehabCare division reported 7% growth in operating income, driven by better cost controls.
    • Home Health and Hospice revenues rose 84% compared to last year.
    • Reaffirms FY13 EPS guidance in-line with Street estimates.
    • Raises FY13 operating cash flow guidance to a range between $235M to $255M from $230M to $250M, and lowers its estimated routine capital expenditures to a range of $112M to $122M from its prior range of $120M to $130M.
    • Shares +5.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:11 PM
  • DSW

    DSW raises FY13 earnings guidance, unveils 2-for-1 stock split

    • DSW (NYSE:DSW) lifts its FY13 earnings guidance and reports same-store sales growth for the second quarter.
    • It now expects full year earnings to come in around $3.60 to $3.80 per share, up from the previous range of $3.40 to $3.60 per share, assuming low single digit same store sales growth for the full year.
    • Net sales came in at approximately $558M for the period ended August 3, compared to $512M for the year-ago period, an increase of approximately 9%.
    • Same store sales, excluding sales from the company's luxury initiative, rose 4.3%, compared to last year's 4.2% increase.
    • The company also unveils plans for a 2-for-1 stock split.
    • Shares +2% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:54 PM
  • VCRA

    Vocera beats by $0.05, beats on revenue

    • Vocera (NYSE:VCRA): Q2 EPS of $0.01 beats by $0.05.
    • Revenue of $25.3M beats by $1.14M. Shares -15.5% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:53 PM
  • LKM

    NQ Mobile again soars to new highs ahead of Q2 report

    • Following today's gains, NQ (NQ +12.7%) is up 197% YTD and 83% since the company's July 15 Q2 pre-announcement.
    • Earlier today, SA contributor/hedge fund manager Treasure Hunter declared NQ "is still dirt cheap" in another bullish write-up (previous). He notes the mobile software firm "is still not followed by a single bulge bracket broker," and didn't have a single 3%+ institutional owner as of a month ago.
    • On Friday, NQ announced it had extended its linchpin mobile security software partnership with China Mobile (in place since 2010).
    • Q2 results (likely to be accompanied by guidance) are due on Aug. 12.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:39 PM
  • TALO

    Stone Energy beats by $0.09, beats on revenue

    • Stone Energy (SGY): Q2 EPS of $0.78 beats by $0.09.
    • Revenue of $245.9M (+8.5% Y/Y) beats by $21M.
    • Shares +2.8% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM

  • After-hours top gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: MKTG +10%. ININ +7%. GTAT +7%. DSW +6%. IMGN +5%.
    • Losers: AEO -18%. MDR -12%. SWHC -6%. SGYP -5%. SNTA -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:31 PM | 5 Comments
  • XCO

    More on EXCO earnings

    • EXCO Resources (NYSE:XCO) Q2 misses on its EPS but beats on revenue.
    • Oil, natural gas and NGL production was 38 Bcfe, or 420 Mmcfe per day, compared with 50 Bcfe, or 550 Mmcfe per day in Q212.
    • Oil, natural gas and NGL revenues were $150M compared with $118M in the prior year.
    • Average sales price per Mcfe increased to $3.93 per Mcfe from $2.36 per Mcfe a year earlier.
    • Operating costs per Mcfe were favorably impacted by the contribution of certain conventional properties stemming from its EXCO/HGI partnership in Q1. Shares +2% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:26 PM
  • THO

    Thor Industries announces record preliminary sales, improved backlog

    • Thor Industries (NYSE:THO) announces preliminary FQ4 sales results: Sales rose 15.2% Y/Y to $1.023B vs. $975.9M consensus.
    • RV backlog on July 31 was $441.5M, up 31.7% Y/Y; towable RV backlog rose 1.7% to $228.4M; motorized RV backlog nearly doubled to $213.1M.
    • Shares +1.9% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:23 PM
  • MDR

    More on McDermott International earnings

    • McDermott International (NYSE:MDR) Q2 misses hard as revenues fell 28% Y/Y on heavy charges.
    • Project-related charges resulted in operating losses in its Asia Pacific and Middle East segments, due to delays on a deepwater pipelay project in Malaysia and a $38M million charge to one project in Saudi Arabia.
    • The company also commenced restructuring of its Atlantic operations, including personnel reductions in Houston and New Orleans as well as a relocation of its Morgan City fabrication and marine activities to Altamira, Mexico.
    • Restructuring costs are expected to range between $45M to $60M.
    • Backlog was approximately $5.1B at the end of June, compared to $5.3B in March. Approximately $375.1M of the backlog was derived from three projects that are currently in a loss position, relating mostly to the project in the Asia Pacific segment and a five-year charter in Brazil.
    • The company announces that its Chief Operating Officer, John T. McCormack, will be retiring in Q4.
    • Shares -11.8% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:05 PM
  • MKTG

    Responsys revenue guidance strong, shares jump to new 52-week highs

    • Responsys (NASDAQ:MKTG) expects Q3 revenue of $47M-$48.5M and EPS of $0.02 vs. a consensus of $46.8M and $0.04
    • 2013 guidance is for revenue of $195M-$198M and EPS of $0.15 vs. a consensus of $192.1M and $0.18.
    • The light EPS guidance is attributed to heavy sales/marketing spend.
    • Q2 subscription revenue +25% Y/Y to $34.3M, services revenue +25% to $15.2M.
    • Opex +42% Y/Y to $29.7M, outpacing rev. growth of 25%.
    • MKTG +10% AH to levels last seen in 2011. Cloud marketing automation software rival Marketo (NASDAQ:MKTO), which took off last week following its Q2 revenue beat, could rally in sympathy.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:02 PM
  • MPO

    Midstates Petroleum misses by $0.10, beats on revenue

    • Midstates Petroleum (NYSE:MPO): Q2 EPS of -$0.06 misses by $0.10.
    • Revenue of $126M beats by $15.42M. Shares -1.6% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:52 PM
  • MDR

    McDermott misses by $0.66, revenue misses

    • McDermott International (NYSE:MDR): Q2 EPS loss of $0.63, misses by $0.66 (may not be comparable).
    • Revenue of $647.3M (-28% Y/Y) misses by $100M. (PR)
    • Shares -11.7% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:49 PM
  • TRW

    TRW Automotive announces secondary offering

    • TRW Automotive (NYSE:TRW) says members of company management and an affiliate of the Blackstone Group will offer a total of 10.9M shares in an underwritten public offering. (PR)
    • Shares -1.7% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM
  • CLNY

    NorthStar Realty Finance to offer shares

    • NorthStar Realty Finance (NRF) slips 3% AH after the company announces plans for a 35M share public offering. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM
  • GTATQ

    GT Advanced EPS beats by $0.06, revenue misses, shares jump

    • GT Advanced Technologies (GTAT): Q2 EPS of $0.15 beats by $0.06.
    • Revenue of $168.3M (+1% Y/Y) misses by $0.7M.
    • Reiterates guidance for 2013 revenue of $500M-$600M and EPS of $0.25-$0.45. Consensus is at $532.2M and $0.29.
    • Shares +8.1% AH. CC at 8AM ET tomorrow (webcast). (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:20 PM | 1 Comment
  • ARTC

    ArthroCare EPS of -$0.27, misses on revenue

    • ArthroCare (NASDAQ:ARTC): Q2 EPS of -$0.27.
    • Revenue of $92.1M misses by $1.57M. Shares +6.1% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM
  • AEO

    American Eagle revises Q2 outlook, shares plunge

    • American Eagle (NYSE:AEO) says Q2 EPS will likely come in around $0.10/ share versus previous guidance of $0.19-0.21/ share.
    • Comps growth is now expected to come in at -7%. (PR)
    • Shares -12.37% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:14 PM
  • JMBA

    More on Jamba's Q2

    • Jamba's (NASDAQ:JMBA) comparable store sales up 2.2% for the quarter.
    • General and administrative expenses down 5.4% Y/Y to help boost operating margin by 230 bps compared to a year ao.
    • The company sees comparable store sales growth of 4% to 6% for FY13 and store-level margin of 20%.
    • JMBA +12% AH on apparent enthusiasm over the firm's outlook.
    • PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:14 PM
  • WPX

    WPX plans to develop San Juan oil discovery

    • WPX Energy (WPX +2.6%) plans to drill 8-10 development wells in New Mexico in 2013 near a San Juan basin oil discovery at which the first four wells flowed at commercial rates.
    • The new field is expected to produce 3,400 boe/day by year-end; WPX says it has already spudded three of the development wells.
    • WPX also continues plans to drill four horizontal Niobrara wells in the Piceance basin in 2013 as a first step in the delineation of its Niobrara discovery.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM
  • NTR

    Potash moves up on sector consolidation chatter

    • Potash (POT +2%) shares enjoy solid gains following remarks by Russian producer Uralkali’s CEO that consolidation would be a logical step for the sector when potash prices fall to a level of marginal producers, though it's too early to predict possible deals as the valuation of individual companies is now unclear.
    • Mosaic (MOS +1.2%) also is higher amid rumors it might be a takeover target for BHP Billiton (BHP +0.3%).
    • Agrium (AGU -0.5%) is left out of the gainers after shares are downgraded at Stifel Nicolaus.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:42 PM
  • HYGS

    Hydrogenics slides again

    • Shares of Hydrogenics (HYGS -6.5%) remain stuck in a post-earnings rut, falling considerably again today, bringing losses since last Wednesday to ~24%.
    • Not helping matters is a downgrade from Ascendiant Capital to Neutral from Buy.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:39 PM
  • REV

    Revlon deal lauded

    • Revlon's (REV +6.1%) deal to buy Colomer looks like a winner to industry watchers.
    • The deal is expected to immediately impact earnings with Colomer's focus in Europe, Africa, and the Middle East complementing Revlon's U.S.-heavy global presence.
    • It also gives Revlon a rapid-fire entry into the professional salon channel.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM
  • OSIR

    Osiris Therapeutics slides after its Q2 EPS fall short

    • Osiris Therapeutics (OSIR -5.1%) slips after it Q2 missed estimates earlier this morning.
    • Product revenue beat, up 231% from Q212, but its net loss was $0.11 per share, wider than estimates for a $0.09 loss.
    • R&D expenses declined, but higher SG&A costs due to increased commercial activity cut into it bottom line.
    • Gross margin improved to 72% compared to 66% in the prior year period.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:24 PM
  • GMCR

    Green Mountain perks up after Barron's-induced hangover

    • After spending the morning in the red following a downbeat Barron's mention over the weekend, shares of Green Mountain Coffee (GMCR +3.4%) move higher in afternoon trading.
    • "We expect the company to announce at least one new partnership (in a new channel) and extend its existing deal with The J.M. Smucker Company in the upcoming weeks and months," KeyBanc's Akshay Jagdale says, reiterating a Buy rating (PT, $90).
    • More from Jagdale: "We believe sales growth will eventually accelerate on the back of new channel penetration, brewer innovation, international expansion, new beverage opportunities, and stabilization of share losses." That pretty much covers it — what's not to like?
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM
  • TECK

    Teck Resources a top pick at FBR to buck production costs

    • FBR Capital adds Teck Resources (TCK +0.7%) to its Top Picks list as the company has deferred some less attractive projects, reduced cash flow breakeven as capex is reduced in the short term, maintains a solid balance sheet with a debt/total cap ratio of 36%; and should benefit from an eventual met coal price recovery.
    • The firm notes TCK has indicated it will not jeopardize its balance sheet strength or investment grade rating, and it will focus on strong cash flow generating assets.
    • Consol Energy (NYSE:CNX) is FBR's favorite steam-coal play; the firm downgrades Alpha Natural Resources (ANR +3%) to Market Perform.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:15 PM
  • GALT

    Galectin Therapeutics slides despite promising new data on its lung fibrosis therapy

    • Galectin Therapeutics (GALT -4.9%) slips again today, despite saying new preclinical data on the efficacy of GR-MD-02, its anti-galectin therapy for lung fibrosis, was effective in reducing the disease.
    • The trials used a model that simulates the human disease idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
    • In it, treatment with GR-MD-02 showed a robust effect in reducing lung fibrosis, with somewhat lesser effect of GM-CT-01.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM | 3 Comments
  • CXM

    Cardium Therapeutics files a new 510K submission with the FDA for Excellagen

    • Cardium Therapeutics (CXM +3.3%) gains after it files a new 510(k) submission for its current FDA-cleared Excellagen advanced wound care product
    • The new submission reflects updated information on specific structural and functional properties of the drug from ongoing supplemental R&D.
    • The findings including electron microscopy data that should allow for more specific labeling to include the unique structural and biological properties of Excellagen and its to potential to enhance platelet activation when used in concert with Platelet Rich Plasma therapy.
    • Additionally, the company plans to modify the drug's packaging to include individually pouched applicator syringes and a large volume syringe applicator to allow for easier use in larger-sized wounds.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:39 PM
  • CBOE

    CBOE falls on Goldman downgrade

    • Goldman says its downgrade of CBOE (CBOE -4.4%), which comes in the wake of the options exchange's FQ1 report, is a valuation call.
    • Shares currently trade at 24x 2013E EPS, and remain up 67% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:34 PM | 1 Comment
  • TSN

    Tyson's meaty quarter helps peers

    • Shares of Tyson Foods (TSN +4.3%) are higher after the company surprised analysts with a brisk quarter led by steady demand for chicken, pork, and beef products. The trend of restaurants and consumers moving toward a higher mix of lower-margin chicken products seems to have abated, which is also welcome relief for Tyson.
    • Peers are out-performing market averages for the days on the good sector news. SFD +0.1%, HRL +0.2%, PPC +0.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:22 PM
  • IONS

    Needham sees weakness in Isis as buying opportunity

    • Needham's Chad Messer doesn't want investors to fret over Isis Pharmaceutical's (ISIS -2.6%) decision to discontinue development of ISIS-CRP treatment for rheumatoid arthritis.
    • In fact, Messer thinks today's weakness may be a buying opportunity as he never thought RA was "a serious consideration" for ISIS-CRP in the first place.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:14 PM | 1 Comment
  • ROYL

    Royale Energy shoots higher after issuing Q2 results

    • Royale Energy (OTC:ROYL +8.4%) reports Q2 EPS of $0.14 vs. $0.01 single analyst estimate, and revenues up 75.5% Y/Y to $1.54M vs $2.4M single estimate. (10-Q)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM
  • WDC

    Nikkei: SanDisk, Toshiba to build ¥400B ($4.1B) fab

    • Nikkei's report about a new NAND flash fab to be built by SanDisk (SNDK -1.1%) and Toshiba (OTCPK:TOSBF) comes amidst growing analyst fears new capacity additions will lead the current NAND up cycle to peak, in spite of strong smartphone/tablet/SSD-related demand.
    • DRAMeXchange recently estimated NAND contract prices fell 6%-9% in 2H July. The firm says the market has been "more sluggish than expected" in Q3.
    • SanDisk is lower, but rival Micron (MU +3.7%) is rallying, possibly thanks to the SIA's June/Q2 sales data. The trade association estimates DRAM sales rose 22% Q/Q in Q2. Flash memory sales are believed to have risen 8.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:51 PM | 4 Comments
  • RPRX

    Repros dips on concern over the validity of its Androxal patent

    • Repros Therapeutics (RPRX -2.8%) dips on a negative article in TheStreet.com saying the company is worried about the validity of its Androxal patent.
    • Despite reassurances by RPRX, recent action it's taken to obtain a declaratory judgment affirming its intellectual property rights in a Texas court suggests the company is actually much more worried than it lets on about the risk of it being invalidated.
    • A New York urologist has accused RPRX CEO Joe Podolski of stealing the idea for Androxal from him after a face-to-face meeting in New York City.
    • Podolski denies Fisch's theft charge, but Repros began developing the drug after the meeting between the two men.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:47 PM
  • TKR

    Timken rises as Relational ups stake

    • Shares of Timken (TKR +1.2%) move higher midday after Relational Investors ups its stake in the company to 7.9% from 6.9% (13-D/A)
    • The SEC filing indicates that Relational has "met with members of [TKR's] special committee and representatives of Goldman Sachs." The activist fund is apparently confident that the company will decide to split its steel and bearings businesses.
    • See our previous coverage of the Timken/ Relational/ CalSTRS saga.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:46 PM
  • NTP

    Nam Tai plunges after providing Q2 results, bleak outlook

    • Excluding $30.7M in revenue from Nam Tai's (NTE -14.5%) discontinued tablet LCD manufacturing ops, Q2 revenue rose 64% Y/Y to $167.9M.
    • Gross margin was 9.6%, up from 4.1% in Q1 but down from 15% a year ago.
    • Nam Tai halted manufacturing at its Wuxi, China tablet LCD facility (previous) at the end of May "due to a lack of new customer orders and after it was unsuccessful in finding a joint venture partner." The company is looking to sell the facility.
    • Nam Tai's Shenzhen facility has received a smartphone LCD order in Q3 from "an existing customer" (Apple?), but the customer is still expected to move production to a lower-cost supplier in time.
    • Customer orders are expected to remain "volatile," with continued price pressure, and the amount of EMS services provided by Nam Tai is expected to be "further reduced significantly."
    • All "commercially viable alternatives" are being explored to continue LCD manufacturing. Also, Nam Tai is looking to convert another Shenzhen facility into "a high-end commercial complex."
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 1:28 PM | 3 Comments
  • VHC

    VirnetX joins list of IP firms selling off following White House veto

    • VirnetX (VHC -4.3%) has joined InterDigital and Acacia in trading lower after the Obama administration vetoed an ITC sales ban on older iPhones/iPads ruled to be infringing standards-essential Samsung IP.
    • The ruling has raised concerns about the ITC's effectiveness as a vehicle to pursue infringement complaints, particularly ones involving standards-essential patents.
    • VirnetX announced in February it would withdraw its ITC complaint against Apple, after obtaining a favorable Texas jury verdict.
    • In June, the White House announced executive actions and legislative proposals aimed at perceived patent trolls.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:01 PM | 1 Comment
  • PRGO

    Luck of the Irish: Jazz, Alkermes rally on deal speculation

    • Perrigo's (NASDAQ:PRGO) recent deal for Elan has investors all jazzed up about Irish-domiciled healthcare companies.
    • The allure of a 12.5% corporate tax rate could mean more M&A activity in the not-so-distant future for "anything with an Irish corporate tax structure," one analyst tells Bloomberg.
    • Some of the names being tossed about: Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ +3.2%) and Alkermes (ALKS +3.8%).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM
  • CRIS

    Curis gains on a solid Q2 report

    • Curis (CRIS +2.5%) moves up after its Q2 easily topped estimates this morning.
    • Revenue grew by 25% Y/Y, primarily the result of an increase in royalties received from Genentech/Roche's net sales of Erivedge and its achievement of certain clinical objectives in its ongoing Phase 1 clinical study of CUDC-907.
    • The company currently anticipates that it will end 2013 with around $49M to $54M in cash and equivalents, which includes the $6M milestone payment that it earned in July related to the conditional approval of Erivedge in the European Union.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:52 PM

  • Midday top 10 gainers / Losers

    • Midday top 10 gainers: SPEX +153%. MCOX +98%. CGEN +41%. CADC +39%. STXS +28%. VIAS +27%. PULS-OLD +26%. PTNT +21%. ONTX +20%. DATE +20%.
    • Losers: GSE -35%. KONE -17%. NTE -15%. SNMX -13%. MIG -12%. CEMI -11%. SSP -10%. BSDM -9%. GIG -8%. PBMD -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • UAN

    CVR Partners hits 52-week low following Q2 results

    • CVR Partners (UAN -4.7%) hits a 52-week low in an apparent delayed reaction to Q2 results that included sharply lower FY 2013 guidance to reflect lower fertilizer prices available in H2 as well as the impact of an unexpected plant shutdown.
    • Blogger Chris Damas forecasts a reduction in FY 2013 cash distributions from $2.15-$2.45/unit to $1.80-$1.90; since $1.19 was paid in H1, it would indicate a combined Q3-Q4 2013 distribution of $0.61-$0.81/unit.
    • Damas calculates CVR's Q3 ammonia production will come in at 96K tons vs. 104K a year ago.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • POR

    Porland General cut to Neutral at DA Davidson

    • Portland General Electric (POR -1.1%) hits new lows today after DA Davidson cut the shares from Buy to Neutral and lowers its price target from $35 to $33 on the back of weaker FY13 guidance.
    • The northwest utility reported a Q2 loss on Friday and lowered its full-year 2013 earnings guidance to $1.25 to $1.40 per share, which is a $0.10 decrease from its earlier June 3 guidance revision of $1.35 to $1.50.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:32 PM
  • Z

    Zillow adds to gains following news of Obama event

    • Pres. Obama will answer housing-related questions during a 1PM ET Wednesday "virtual housing roundtable discussion" hosted by Zillow (Z +5.6%), and moderated by CEO Spencer Rascoff.
    •  "U.S. homeowners, renters and prospective buyers" can ask questions via Facebook and Twitter.
    • Zillow shares have added to the big gains they saw last week in response to Trulia's (TRLA +6.4%) Q2 report. Trulia is also rallying to new post-IPO highs.
    • Zillow's Q2 report arrives tomorrow.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:23 PM
  • ENZ

    Federal Judge upholds $48.6M judgement in favor of Enzo Biochem

    • Enzo Biochem (ENZ +8.6%) jumps after a Federal Court Judge upholds the jury verdict issued in November, 2012, which awarded the drug developer $48.6M in damages as a result of patent infringement by Applera Corporation, which is now Life Technologies (LIFE -0.1%).
    • The court ruled initially that LIFE infringed on ENZ's patent covering pioneering technologies relating to compounds used in DNA sequencing systems to read genetic code.
    • The Judge also denied LIFE's request for a finding that Enzo's infringement claims are barred by laches and/or equitable estoppel and its motion for a new trial, as well as ENZ's request for reconsideration seeking additional damages.
    • The ruling opens the way for ENZ to recover prejudgment interest on the damages award, which should exceed $25M in addition to the judgment.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:22 PM
  • CHFS

    Sunshine Heart jumps on an upbeat report from Runway Research

    • Sunshine Heart (SSH +17%) pops on a report out of Runway Research saying the company's C-Pulse Heart Assist System is a "game changing device" that could lead to a buyout worth as much as $50 per share.
    • SSH received unconditional FDA approval for the C-Pulse(NYSE:R) system's U.S. pivotal trial in November, 2012.
    • With the device, Runway says that SSH is targeting the New York Heart Association's Class III and ambulatory Class IV Congestive Heart Failure market, which is an enormous untapped opportunity with approximately 1.5M patients in the U.S. and another 3.7M patients in Europe.
    • If the company penetrates just 10% of this market, the firm says the opportunity could reach over $5B.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:09 PM
  • XPO

    XPO Logistics lower after filing for secondary offering

    • Shares of XPO Logistics (XPO -5.4%) trail off after the company announces a secondary offering of 8M shares of its common stock.
    • SEC filing
     
     
     
     
    | 11:56 AM | 1 Comment
  • CLF

    Cliffs share surge on Bloom Lake labor agreement

    • Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF +4%) rallies after Friday's news that it had reached a tentative agreement with the United Steelworkers Union on a three-year labor contract covering about 300 workers at its Bloom Lake mine in Quebec.

  • CYD

    China Yuchai posts a solid Q2; shares higher

    • China Yuchai (CYD +8.4%) trades up after easily beating Q2 estimates this morning.
    • Net revenue rose 23.9% Y/Y. Operating profit was RMB 333.8B, +59% from the prior year as gross profit largely offset a gain in operating expenses.
    • Total number of engines rose by 29%, totaling 141,147 units compared with 109,329 units in Q212.
    • The company attributes the volume gain to an increase in sales of engines for agriculture and truck applications, and and higher sales of commercial vehicles due to the pre-buying of trucks prior to the implementation of the National IV emission standards that went into effect nationwide on July 1.

InterDigital (IDCC -10.1%) and Acacia (ACTG -2.5%) shares are selling off today, apparently on concerns about the ruling's impact for the companies' own ITC infringement suits (I, II).
    • In justifying the veto, U.S. trade rep. Michael Froman said he "strongly shares" concerns raised by the DOJ and USPTO about ITC bans being issued in cases involving standards-essential patents.

  • BLRX

    BioLineRx's BL-8040 treatment effective in pre-clinical trials

    • BioLineRx's (BLRX +1.6%) BL-8040 drug was effective in treating thrombocytopenia, or reduced platelet production, in pre-clinical trials of healthy mice as well as those with chemotherapy induced-thrombocytopenic.
    • "BL-8040 significantly increased the number of megakaryocytes (cells that produce platelets) within the bone marrow," BioLineRx says. "This was associated with increased production and increased levels of platelets in the blood" in both types of mice.
    • BL-8040 also increased the number of hematopoietic progenitor cells within the bone marrow and in the blood. These are important for generating "the whole gamut of red and white blood cells."
    • BL-8040 cut the severity and duration of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia and cytopenia.
    • BioLineRx is developing BL-8040 for acute myeloid leukemia, for which the drug is undergoing Phase II trials. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:45 AM | 1 Comment
